12.18.19  6:20 pm   hi

i've found myself creating lots of content but instead of releasing it all at once i've had it scheduled for one every week. from here i'm realizing that i'm scheduling stuff that won't take place until next decade ... or maybe even longer than a WHOLE MONTH from the time of actually creating it. have you ever had a situation with finished content but not publishing until later?

      and if so, did you write in the dates on the published date or the original finish date?

      i'm not fully sure which is better, but i've been using the publish date as when it was "made."

have a nice day.

html:
12.18.19  4:21 pm   12.17.19  10:40 pm the reason you don't hear about people doing this is because it's not very intuitive or obvious that this is what you should do. but it works, at least for me. even for entirely unrelated fields such as app development. building a bunch of tiny apps that do simple things is a much better way of learning than spending a ton of time on one huge project that i never end up finishing


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201912172240

12.17.19  10:40 pm   so i've written drafts for a bunch of songs, and i like them, but i'm kind of worried they're actually all terrible and suck. should i care? does it matter? should i try and finalize and publish them or just hoard them? idk what to do please advise

     i will recommend this all day, even though it probably doesn't work for anyone besides me. but wow oh wow it really worked for me, to help with this exact problem. if you experiencing too much pressure and fear about the entire song creation process, try doing much shorter songs. you will learn your way around every aspect of the song creation process quicker, and you will be able to easily scale up your operations gradually from there. i have started to realize this probably doesn't work for anyone other than me, because i never hear about anyone doing this. but it has worked so insanely well for me, i owe my entire life to this method
original_html: 12.18.19  4:21 pm   12.17.19  10:40 pm the reason you don't hear about people doing this is because it's not very intuitive or obvious that this is what you should do. but it works, at least for me. even for entirely unrelated fields such as app development. building a bunch of tiny apps that do simple things is a much better way of learning than spending a ton of time on one huge project that i never end up finishing

     i will recommend this all day, even though it probably doesn't work for anyone besides me. but wow oh wow it really worked for me, to help with this exact problem. if you experiencing too much pressure and fear about the entire song creation process, try doing much shorter songs. you will learn your way around every aspect of the song creation process quicker, and you will be able to easily scale up your operations gradually from there. i have started to realize this probably doesn't work for anyone other than me, because i never hear about anyone doing this. but it has worked so insanely well for me, i owe my entire life to this method
